posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked:
We are experiencing some jumps in our odometry. We are using SwerveDrivePoseEstimator with LL3G using Metatag 2. When we update the wheel’s position we use the update function and give it the robot rotation and module positions. When we update with vision we use addVisionMeasurement and pass the LL3G pose and the estimated pose timestamp.

Did anyone encounter this jumping behavior?

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
Is the jumped to position more accurate? Are you getting vision measurements all along or only when you get close and slow down (up by the speaker where the jump happens).   More observations means smaller jumps but sometimes it is hard to get a good observation while moving especially if you have a rolling shutter camera.

The difficulty in vision odometry comes with tuning the standard deviations of the vision measurement, that is how much the pose estimator should trust that over wheel odometry.  A large jump to a bad location could be poorly tuned deviations.

Sorry this doesn’t help much but may give you some places to start looking.

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked:
Your vision seems to be working fine; it’s just that the pose estimation is moving toward the vision estimation too fast.  This is because the standard deviation of your vision is too low.  In other words, the PoseEstimator “trusts” your vision estimations TOO MUCH and changes the pose estimation too fast.

You can specify the standard deviation like this:

Or set the standard deviation permenantly like this:

If you are using one camera, I recommend trying 0.7 meters for translation and 30 degrees for rotation first.

Also, you should have some filtering mechanism.  For example, reject the vision estimation if the height, pitch, or roll of the position estimation exceeds a threshold.  Because they should be 0 if your robot is on the ground.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Our odometry is preety accurate as well as our vision. I think it may be somthing to do with latency

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: Yes, you need to subtract the latency from the current timestamp to eliminate the latency issues. Also, ensure that your AprilTags are correctly installed as it seems the first jump is the opposite of the second jump.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: Another possible explanation could be an issue with the limelight. We tested the Limelight 3G and found that the position is precise but not accurate, especially at large angles. I believe this may be caused by the lens, as there could be some distortion with a wide field of view (FOV). As a result, your position can be inconsistent and causing the jumping behavior.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Have you calibrated your LL ? How accurate exactly? Without calibration you could be off by 10% easily, but it’ll still seem to be precise. To say nothing if a potential bad tag layout if you swapped tag IDs or mounted them weirdly.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
